q.a: for me there were always too many ways, which actually made it impossible. there were always 100 ways i 'could' just pursue a career working for someone else as a side person.  but i guess i just was too picky, and also crazy, so the only thing that made sense was to do everything myself, and there were always strong signs that that was possible because i have always picked up skills easily from a young age. but the more skills i got, the bigger and more insane the ideas and goals got. and i was just drowning and had no idea how to figure out what to do. and as time passed, it only got bigger and bigger and more insane. but i began documenting my journey early on, which sort of helped tie the entire struggle together into one cohesive story. and sure enough, after a few more chapters, and a few more layers of unmanageble expansion, just when i thought i was in way too deep to ever find my way, i just snapped and started a brute force approach which was to just start doing 5 'things' a week, ruthlessly, and never stopping, and posting it online. and then evolving the project from there, as needed, knowing that once it's underway i can surely steer it to hit every corner in due time

q.a: yes. i was trying to do a mixed content schedule, with assorted short/medium videos, leading up to some 2min and 3min songs. but people got really really angry about the short videos, especially the 5-6 second ones. i realized i really don't even need to do those anymore. the only reason i was doing it was to keep the fans 'happy' and keep uploads happening. when i saw the rage i figured what's the point. there was also anger about 'not doing another history video' which i really don't care about, because i gotta do what i'm gonna do. but then i saw people come to my defense and say 'he only wanted to do 1 history video' that was when i realized something was wrong. the japan one was just for practice. it was not supposed to be the only one. so that's when i knew it was time to go all the way and get it over with, before moving on to the next major egg to crack, which is a regularly scheduled stream of medium / full length song releases forever

q.a: analysis, making connections, categorizing things, ... all that stuff is wonderful, and i think it's an art, not a science. you can treat it as science, but you will surely run into trouble if you ever run into jokesters
q.q: i feel like you're very quick to put the kabosh on analogous thinking, stepping in with an implication to remind the asker that the subjects in question are not entirely alike at all, and are both wonderful and terrible in their own ways. You do this with common structures for questions, as well. I have a great respect for it, because it feels like you're stopping generalization and forcing people to look even harder at things. However, I am in a cognitive science class, and it is teaching me that analogy is fairly specific to humans, and it might be what has allowed us to advance beyond other species. We can apply learned information in a highly abstract way to many facets of our lives when we recognize similar structure, whereas other animals cannot. So now I am torn! What do you make of this?

q.a: in general, the verses are 3 keys 'sharper' than the chorus. the verses are in Eb (or Cmin) and the chorus is in Gb (Ebmin)
q.q: s there any way you can explain the key changes in this song https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=POfOycet4bE (except the obvious first one at 0:12)?

q.a: going from the chorus to the verse, they use Eb as a pivot point, because Eb minor exists normally in Gb, and if you arrive at Ebminor but then use Eb major instead, then that sets you up to go forward in an Eb maj key (or Cmin).
q.q: it sounds like there is no key change from the chorus to the verse at 1:30-1:40 (same as 0:12-0:22)

q.a: going from the verse to the chorus they do not use that pivot point, they jump from the G7 (which sounds like it is setting up for Cmin) and immediately go to Bma7 (as b6 of the new Ebmin key)
q.q: but i know something weird must be going on here because of the super surprising key change at 2:23, putting it back in the same key it was at 0:12

q.a: start practicing with a metronome. take it as slow as you need so you can actually sight read it. when you run out of tunes, get another book -- try to get one with actual tempo markings so that way you can keep track of what your handicap is, relative to the song's actual tempo, and that way you can very gradually increase the tempo. also a good technique is learning to look ahead. i know that seems crazy but that is really how you get it done

Play this thing now or not at all" so I'm trying excercises where I just flip to a random piece in "the real book" and play it as accurately and fast as possible. q.q: I have analyzed your song "New Canaan" and came to the conclusion that the song is about a guy who's going to prison and he's addressing to his daughter that he killed.My evidence is 1. you like singing about jail/prison 2. there is a federal prison in Pennsylvania called "Canaan" 3. the narrator is unreliable as he suffered a nervous breakdown as told by "I'm going crazy". 4. He's riding on a train (on his way to prison) and he's hungry for food and women (he's not gonna see a woman again any time soon) 5. He talks about "loving the shade of those license plates" i.e. he's making license plates, a stereotypical prison job.My theory is that he loved his daughter and went crazy before killing her and his nervous breakdown only got worse as he got sentenced to life in prison so he wrote this song to say what he wants to tell his dead daughter whom he loved dearly. As he's "talking" to his daughter, he feels the need as a father to protect her from the truth, and "lies about details" by saying he's "actually going to connecticut"At first he tries to convince himself that it's all for the better and that he's happy, evidenced by how he says he hopes the train doesn't get derailed, and how "the season is winter, and the sky is so blue" but gradually comes back to reality and understands the severity of the situation, as line "it's summer and the sky has turned grey and my dreams are sailing away" indicates he has spent enough time in prison for the seasons to change. On a scale of 100% to 100%, how close is my interpretation?

P.s. I know you said you wrote the song after picking New Canaan as a random town to take the train and wrote the song on the way there. I just don't buy that such poetry would have such a straightforward explanation.
